Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Investigating effects of geologic complexity on induced seismicity, using M0-M5.7 seismicity from Prague, Oklahoma
Award.AbstractNarration: The recent surge in induced seismicity in the Midwestern United States, during which Oklahoma has catapulted past California in seismicity rate, has created controversy, captured the attention of the general public, and influenced policy. As a result, induced seismicity has become a focal point of earthquake science in the United States over the last few years; however, much remains to be learned about the mechanisms of induced seismicity. In this research the well-recorded 2011 Prague, OK earthquake sequence will be used to investigate deformation on a scale not commonly obtainable in seismicity studies (earthquake location with precision ~10 meters). Such well-located earthquakes allow for better understanding of how complex faults fail. Furthermore, laboratory experiments on the rocks from the Prague area will provide information on how strong and stable the faults are, and how pumping fluids into the faults might promote earthquakes.<br/><br/>The Prague sequence contains three earthquakes greater than Mw5 and their robust aftershock sequences, as well as the foreshock sequences for two large events. The precision with which the Prague earthquakes can be located allows the failure processes to be considered on a scale comparable to fault structures measured in studies of exhumed faults. In addition, complementary laboratory experiments on lithologies from the Prague area will allow study of the effects of fluid pressure on fault strength and stability. The ultimate goal is to use the Prague dataset to probe the influence of fluid pressure and fault zone complexity on earthquake nucleation, propagation, and arrest. Specifically this work will address the following questions: 1) Do the faults near Prague show precursory activity that could be used to forecast rupture? 2) How does complex fault geometry control rupture? and 3) How do fault strength, strength heterogeneity, and fault stability play a role in induced earthquakes?

POR.DRECONTENT:
Induced seismicity, or earthquakes that are related to human activity such as waste-water disposal, poses a risk to people and infrastructure. In the 2010s, induced earthquakes became very common in the midwestern United States and in particularly in Oklahoma.  The 2011 Prague OK earthquake sequence consisted of three earthquakes greater than magnitude 5 and their associated foreshocks and aftershocks.  The earthquakes were well recorded due to the deployment of several local seismometers. This grant used the earthquake catalog generated during that sequence to investigate how such a complex earthquake was generated. Specifically, we used the occurrence of small, nearly identical earthquakes known as repeating earthquakes as a proxy for times when the faults in the vicinity were slipping slowly rather than quickly like they do in earthquakes. Such slow slip can alleviate stress in some areas but also load faults in other regions that might be more likely to generate earthquakes in the future. We find that slow slip is most likely to be generated at the intersection of multiple faults. In addition, we studied the frictional properties of the rocks where the earthquakes were occurring by using drillcores that were taken from the relevant lithologies. The frictional properties and the stress conditions underground can lead to a fault to either slip slowly or in an earthquake, and this is an important distinction to be able to make to be able to assess seismic hazard. We studied friction of faults with different pore fluid pressures to determine whether high pore fluid pressures that might be expected in areas of induced seismicity changed the faults ability to restrengthen (heal) but the data suggest that high fluid pressures do not inhibit healing.

 


Last Modified: 09/30/2022
Modified by: Heather M Savage
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Induced seismicity, or earthquakes that are related to human activity such as waste-water disposal, poses a risk to people and infrastructure. In the 2010s, induced earthquakes became very common in the midwestern United States and in particularly in Oklahoma. The 2011 Prague OK earthquake sequence consisted of three earthquakes greater than magnitude 5 and their associated foreshocks and aftershocks. The earthquakes were well recorded due to the deployment of several local seismometers. This grant used the earthquake catalog generated during that sequence to investigate how such a complex earthquake was generated. Specifically, we used the occurrence of small, nearly identical earthquakes known as repeating earthquakes as a proxy for times when the faults in the vicinity were slipping slowly rather than quickly like they do in earthquakes. Such slow slip can alleviate stress in some areas but also load faults in other regions that might be more likely to generate earthquakes in the future. We find that slow slip is most likely to be generated at the intersection of multiple faults. In addition, we studied the frictional properties of the rocks where the earthquakes were occurring by using drillcores that were taken from the relevant lithologies. The frictional properties and the stress conditions underground can lead to a fault to either slip slowly or in an earthquake, and this is an important distinction to be able to make to be able to assess seismic hazard. We studied friction of faults with different pore fluid pressures to determine whether high pore fluid pressures that might be expected in areas of induced seismicity changed the faults ability to restrengthen (heal) but the data suggest that high fluid pressures do not inhibit healing.
